case_name: Legal representatives of Tuljaramarao Narainrao Desai v. Rao Ba. Vithalrao Laxmanrao Thube

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 716 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 716 of 1957.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and decree dated July 29, 1955 of the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 50 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 29, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 50 of 1953 under the Letters Patent against the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1953, of the said High Court in First Appeal No. 547 of 1952.

facts.text: Shah J of Bombay High Court passed order dated September 23, 1953 in First Appeal No. 547 of 1952 setting aside the executing court's order of attachment.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeal was heard by Shah, J., who by his order dated September 23, 1953, set aside the order of attachment relying on the decision of Chagla, J., in second Appeal No. 760 of 1942.

facts.text: Division Bench of Bombay High Court reversed Shah J's decision and restored the executing court's order in Letters Patent Appeal No. 50 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench, as already stated, reversed the decision of Shah, J. and restored the order made by the executing court.

facts.text: Laxmanrao brought Civil Suit No. 313 of 1943 against Tuljaramarao to recover Rs. 80,000 borrowed by Tuljaramarao from Laxmanrao.

anchor.surface_text: One Rao Ba. Vithalrao Laxmanrao Thube, hereinafter referred to as Laxmanrao, brought Civil Suit No. 313 of 1943 against Tuljaramarao Narainrao Desai, hereinafter referred to as Tuljaramarao, to recover Rs. 80,000 which had been borrowed by him from the plaintiff.

facts.text: Laxmanrao's suit was decreed on December 20, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Laxmanraos suit was decreed on December 20, 1943.

facts.text: Tuljaramarao died and his legal representatives, the appellants, were brought on record on September 21, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Tuljaramarao having died his legal representatives, the present appellants, were brought on the record on September 21, 1944.

facts.text: In April 1949, Laxmanrao filed application for execution of the decree seeking attachment of properties including the Wada.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1949, Laxmanrao filed an application for the execution of the decree. He sought the attachment, with a view to their subsequent sale, of certain properties including the Wada which is the subject-matter of this appeal.

facts.text: Executing court issued warrant of attachment against the Wada on December 17, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The executing court on December 17, 1951, issued a warrant of attachment only against the Wada in question.

facts.text: Appellants objected to the attachment of the Wada.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants objected to the proposed attachment on various grounds.

facts.text: The whole village Nandi was granted as inam to ancestor of Tuljaramarao and descendants per Sanad Ext. 54 and Inam Patrak Ext.

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed that the whole of village Nandi had been granted as inam to the ancestor of Tuljaramarao and his descendants as per Sanad, Ext. 54, and the Inam Patrak, Ext. In that Sanad there is no mention of any Wada existing on the Inam land.

facts.text: No mention of any Wada in the Sanad.

anchor.surface_text: In that Sanad there is no mention of any Wada existing on the Inam land.

facts.text: The Wada was built after the grant of the inam.

anchor.surface_text: According to the executing court the Wada appears to have been built after the grant. It appears that- the opinion of the Division Bench of the High Court was also to the same effect.

facts.text: Appellants claimed the Wada is Watan property and cannot be attached.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J., relied upon the decision of Chagla, J., and held that the land on which the Wada in the present case stood, being Watan property, the Wada must also be deemed to have acquired that character.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the Wada is not Watan property.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, at no time was it held for providing remuneration for the performance of the duty appertaining to a hereditary office.

facts.text: Tuljaramarao reserved about 35 acres for home farm about 8 years before his death, maintained 12 bullocks and 8 servants, income Rs. 20,000-25,000 per year.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the evidence of the appellants own witness, Balaji, shows that Tuljaramarao had reserved some lands for a home farm about 8 years before his death. The area reserved was about 35 acres and that he maintained about 12 bullocks and 8 servants.

facts.text: Cattle, servants, agricultural implements and produce were kept in the Wada by Tuljaramarao.

anchor.surface_text: He used to keep his cattle in the Wada where his servants also stayed and his agricultural implements were kept. The produce of the lands was also stored in the Wada.

facts.text: Appasaheb increased home farm to 60 acres, has 14 bullocks, 10-12 servants, income Rs. 30,000-35,000 per year.

anchor.surface_text: Appasaheb increased the acreage of the cultivation of the home farm to about 60 acres. He has 14 bullocks and 10 or 12 servants and the income is Rs. 30,000 to Rs. 35,000 a year.

facts.text: Appasaheb has inams in 4 villages and owns lands in 10-12 villages with income Rs. 35,000-40,000.

anchor.surface_text: This witness also stated that the appellant Appasaheb had inams in 4 villages. Furthermore, in 10 or 12 villages he owns lands and he gets about Rs. 35,000 to Rs. 40,000 from his lands.

facts.text: Appasaheb and brother sometimes worked personally in the fields.

anchor.surface_text: The said Appasabeb and his brother sometimes worked personally in the fields.

facts.text: Appellants claimed the Wada is exempted from attachment as house of agriculturist under s.60 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that as the word agriculturist has not been defined in the Code, the word must be construed according to its ordinary meaning.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that appellants are not agriculturists within meaning of s.60 CPC proviso cl.(c).

anchor.surface_text: From this point of view it seems to us that he cannot be regarded as an agriculturist within the meaning of that word in s. 60 of the Code.

facts.text: Appasaheb receives cash allowance Rs.700-800 per annum and Rs.4,000-5,000 from village officers of four inam villages.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the appellant Appasaheb is receiving a cash allowance of Rs. 700 to Rs. 800 per annum and Rs. 4,000 to Rs. 5,000 from the village, officers of the four inam villages.

facts.text: The appeal was dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decision of the High Court that the Wada in question was not Watan property and that it was not exempted from attachment by virtue of the provisions of s. 60 (1) of the Code is correct. The appeal is accordingly dismissed with costs.

facts.text: A.K. Sarkar J delivered a separate judgment dissenting on the agriculturist issue.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of Jafer Imam and Raghubar Dayal, JJ., was delivered by Jafer Imam, J. A. K. Sarkar, J., delivered a separate judgment.

arguments.claim: The Wada is Watan property because it is an accession to the Watan land on which it stands and partakes of the same character.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J., relied upon the decision of Chagla, J., and held that the land on which the Wada in the present case stood, being Watan property, the Wada must also be deemed to have acquired that character.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: xtent at least it appears to be clear that the Wada in question does number companye within the definition of Watan property as defined in the Act. Th

arguments.court_reasoning: Wada not held or acquired for remuneration of hereditary duty; severable from land, not part of original grant.

arguments.claim: House built on Watan land is immovable property held for hereditary duty per s.4 BHOA and Bombay General Clauses Act definition.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the definition of immoveable property in the Bombay General Clauses Act he was of the opinion that the house certainly formed part of the immoveable property which was held for the performance of the duty appertaining to the hereditary office of the Watan.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ty appertaining to an hereditary office and therefore were Watan properties. On the findings of the companyrts below the Wada in question was number t

arguments.court_reasoning: House must independently satisfy s.4 definition; not held for duty remuneration.

arguments.claim: A house subsequently built on Watan land does not become Watan property unless it satisfies s.4 test independently.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench which heard the appeal against the decision of Shah, J., was of the opinion that although a house built on land must be regarded as immoveable property it did not follow that like the land on which it was built the house became Watan property.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to the companytrary in the Sanad, that the grantee was number restricted from companystructing a building on the land. From that, however, it does nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; Wada post-grant construction not for hereditary duty.

arguments.claim: Wada not subject of original grant, built subsequently, not held/acquired for hereditary duty remuneration per s.4 BHOA.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the courts below the Wada in question was not the subject of the grant. In our opinion, therefore, at no time was it held for providing remuneration for the performance of the duty appertaining to a hereditary office.

arguments.claim: Construction of Wada on Watan land is not accession like imperceptible accretion.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was argued that the Wada is an accession to the Watan property, namely, the land of village Nandi. It seems to us, however, that construction of a Wada on land which is Watan property is not an accession to it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accession implies imperceptible accretion; Wada distinguishable and severable.

arguments.claim: Grantee has full right to construct on land as grantor could; thus Wada partakes of land's character.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was argued that the right, title and interest of the grantor had to be looked at first in construing a grant and if it appeared from the terms thereof that it did not contain any reservation or exception then all the rights, title and interest of the grantor which he was capable of granting would pass to the grantee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d number even exempt his agricultural produce unless there was a numberification under s. 61 of the Code specifying by a general or special order how

arguments.court_reasoning: Watandar not absolute owner; construction severable, can be dismantled without violating Act.

arguments.claim: Wada severable from land, can be dismantled and materials sold; thus not Watan property.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that on a proper construction of the Sanad there was no impediment in the way of the grantee from dismantling the house which he had built and removing the materials with which it had been constructed and selling the same.

arguments.claim: Wada belongs to agriculturist (Appasaheb) and occupied by him, exempt under s.60(1) proviso cl.(c) CPC by ordinary meaning.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that as the word agriculturist has not been defined in the Code, the word must be construed according to its ordinary meaning. According to Shorter Oxford English Dictionary this word can also mean a farmer.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s. Another view taken is that the agriculturist must be one whose sole means of livelihood is cultivation of land but excluding persons carrying on fa

arguments.court_reasoning: Must bear same meaning as cl.(b); dependent on tilling for living, unable otherwise.

arguments.claim: 'Agriculturist' in cl.(c) same as in cl.(b) s.60 proviso; small tiller dependent on soil.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent, however, it was contended that the word agriculturist in cl. c of the proviso must bear the same meaning as the word agriculturist in cl. b of the proviso.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the word agriculturist in cl.  b  and the house must be occupied by him as such. The object of the exemption in el.  c  apparently is that an agricu

arguments.court_reasoning: Proper construction requires same meaning; cl.(b) implies tiller maintaining self from soil.

arguments.claim: Agriculturist personally tills land, livelihood from tillage; not large proprietors using servants (Hanmantrao).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Hanmantrao Annarao v. Dhruvaraj Pandurangrao it was held by the Bombay High Court that the word agriculturist in cls. b and c of the proviso to s. 60 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure denotes persons who are personally engaged in tilling.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in each case appears to me to be different. I find it impossible to say that the central idea was to protect the poor or to prevent a person being lef

arguments.court_reasoning: Personal tilling not required; hired labour ok, but dependent on tilling.

arguments.claim: Agriculturist is real tiller dependent on soil tilling for living, unable otherwise (Parvataneni Lakshmayya FB).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Parvataneni Lakshmayya v. The Official Receiver of Kistna a Full Bench of the Madras High Court arrived at the following conclusion after considering various decisions... an agriculturist in the section is a person who is really dependent for his living on tilling the soil and unable to maintain himself otherwise.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s. Another view taken is that the agriculturist must be one whose sole means of livelihood is cultivation of land but excluding persons carrying on fa

arguments.court_reasoning: Adopted as test; appellants not dependent solely on agriculture.

arguments.claim: Main source of income from cultivation test (Tirloki Prasad).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Tirloki Prasad Kunj Behari Lal the Allahabad High Court held that the test to be applied in deciding whether a person is an agriculturist is whether his main source of income is derived from cultivation or not.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s such cattle and seed- grain as may be necessary to enable him to earn his living as such , that is, as an agriculturist. I do number think that thes

arguments.court_reasoning: Varying/unreasonable; poor peasant could lose protection.

arguments.claim: Cl.(b) applies to large farmers too; protects implements regardless of scale (Dwarka Prasad).

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Dwarka Prasad v. Meerut Municipality where it was held that a tractor was an implement of husbandry and it was not subject to attachment although it was used for cultivating an area of about 1,200 bighas of a farm.

arguments.claim: Agriculturist by occupation/nature, not source; cultivates even with labourers, large/small scale (Gowardhandas).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Gowardhandas v. Mohanlal the conclusions of the Nagpur High Court were Whether a person is an agriculturist or not is not a question turning on source of income but on nature of occupation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: lages, neither of which was income from agriculture. These facts in my view make Appasaheb an agriculturist for the purpose of cls.  b  and  c  though

arguments.court_reasoning: Conflicts with dependency test from cl.(b).

arguments.claim: Exemption per cl.(b)/(c) only for what necessary to earn livelihood; large income disqualifies.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that in the present case the appellant Appasaheb was cultivating a very large area of land with the aid of employed labour and derived an income somewhere between Rs. 30,000 to 35,000 a year.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: lages, neither of which was income from agriculture. These facts in my view make Appasaheb an agriculturist for the purpose of cls.  b  and  c  though

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellants have substantial other income; not dependent.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.60 protects tools/implements/cattle/seed to earn livelihood; implies poor dependent tiller.

anchor.surface_text: Section 60 1 of the Code states in detail what property of a judgment debtor is liable to attachment and sale in the execution of a decree. ... the object of the Code was to save in the case of a judgment debtor his tools as an artisan and, where he was an agriculturist, his implements of husbandry.

arguments.claim: Agriculturist must be dependent on tilling soil for maintenance, unable otherwise; evidence shows appellants not.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that even if it is not necessary that a person must till the land with his own hands to come within the meaning of the word agriculturist he must at least show that he was really dependent for his living on tilling the soil and was unable to maintain himself otherwise.

arguments.claim: Appasaheb cultivates large area with servants, income Rs.30-35k from home farm + other lands Rs.35-40k + allowances; not dependent.

anchor.surface_text: From this point of view it seems to us that he cannot be regarded as an agriculturist within the meaning of that word in s. 60 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Plain meaning: agriculturist any who occupies self with agriculture/cultivation, even large scale with servants, other income ok.
Reject main source test; leads to anomalies (rich farmer protected, poor labourer not).

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore if this view is accepted, a rich farmer who has income from other sources, which income is smaller than his income from agriculture, would be protected by these clauses while a poor peasant who makes a slightly bigger income, say as a day labourer, than he does from agriculture, would be deprived of the protection.

arguments.claim: Reject personal tilling requirement; allows hired labour, old/incapacitated ok.
Parvataneni test wrong; anomalies (rich farmer protected, small with other income not).
No qualification for small/poor only; clauses protect rich too (e.g., pensions).
Appasaheb is agriculturist: cultivates 50-60 acres with own cattle/implements/servants, income 30-35k; occupies Wada for ag purposes.
arguments.court_reasoning: Dissent accepts facts but majority finds not dependent.

arguments.claim: Wada occupied for agriculture: stores crops, implements, servants reside, cattle tethered, supervision.

anchor.surface_text: I think the evidence makes it perfectly clear that he did so. It shows that the larger part of the wada was used for storing crops, keeping agricultural implements, residence of the farm servants and tethering cattle used for agriculture.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: lages, neither of which was income from agriculture. These facts in my view make Appasaheb an agriculturist for the purpose of cls.  b  and  c  though

arguments.claim: Accessio cedit principali: Wada on Watan land acquires Watan character.
arguments.court_reasoning: Maxim doesn't extend inalienable character to post-grant construction; only to granted property.

holdings.text: The Wada is not Watan property because it was not the subject of the original grant, nor held or acquired for providing remuneration for the performance of the duty appertaining to a hereditary office.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the courts below the Wada in question was not the subject of the grant. In our opinion, therefore, at no time was it held for providing remuneration for the performance of the duty appertaining to a hereditary office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies definition in s.4 Bombay Hereditary Offices Act to facts: post-grant construction not part of remuneration; no evidence of purpose for hereditary duty.

holdings.text: A house constructed subsequent to the inam grant on Watan land does not partake of the character of Watan property merely by being immovable property thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench which heard the appeal against the decision of Shah, J., was of the opinion that although a house built on land must be regarded as immoveable property it did not follow that like the land on which it was built the house became Watan property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench view accepted; must independently satisfy s.4 test; rejects automatic accession to land's character.

holdings.text: Construction of a Wada on Watan land is not an accession thereto, as accession implies imperceptible accretion indistinguishable from original land.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was argued that the Wada is an accession to the Watan property, namely, the land of village Nandi. It seems to us, however, that construction of a Wada on land which is Watan property is not an accession to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes accession (imperceptible) from deliberate construction; Wada distinguishable and severable.

holdings.text: The Wada is severable from the Watan land; grantee could dismantle it and sell materials without violating the Act or Sanad.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that on a proper construction of the Sanad there was no impediment in the way of the grantee from dismantling the house which he had built and removing the materials with which it had been constructed and selling the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Watandar not absolute owner; no restriction in Sanad; severability shows not integral to inalienable grant.

holdings.text: The word 'agriculturist' in cl.(c) of proviso to s.60(1) CPC bears the same meaning as in cl.(b).

anchor.surface_text: The word agriculturist in this clause must carry the same meaning as the word agriculturist in cl. b and the house must be occupied by him as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of proviso clauses; cl.(b) implies tiller maintaining self from soil proceeds.

holdings.text: An agriculturist under s.60 CPC proviso is one really dependent for living on tilling the soil and unable to maintain himself otherwise; personal tilling with own hands not required.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that even if it is not necessary that a person must till the land with his own hands to come within the meaning of the word agriculturist he must at least show that he was really dependent for his living on tilling the soil and was unable to maintain himself otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive from cl.(b) exemptions for livelihood necessities; follows Parvataneni Lakshmayya FB, rejects personal tilling (Hanmantrao) and main source (Tirloki); applies to facts showing substantial other income.

holdings.text: Appellants are not agriculturists within s.60 CPC meaning; Wada not exempted from attachment.

anchor.surface_text: From this point of view it seems to us that he cannot be regarded as an agriculturist within the meaning of that word in s. 60 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of large home farm income plus other lands, inams, allowances shows not dependent solely on tilling.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court is correct; appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decision of the High Court that the Wada in question was not Watan property and that it was not exempted from attachment by virtue of the provisions of s. 60 (1) of the Code is correct. The appeal is accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court on both issues.

holdings.text: Appasaheb is an agriculturist under plain meaning in s.60 proviso cls.(b),(c): any person occupying himself with agriculture/cultivation, regardless of scale, servants, or other income.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects dependency, personal tilling, main source tests as anomalous/unwarranted by text; plain dictionary meaning; protects large farmers too per policy of other clauses.

holdings.text: Wada belongs to and is occupied by agriculturist Appasaheb for agricultural purposes, exempted under cl.(c) s.60(1) CPC.

anchor.surface_text: I think the evidence makes it perfectly clear that he did so. It shows that the larger part of the wada was used for storing crops, keeping agricultural implements, residence of the farm servants and tethering cattle used for agriculture.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts: supervision, storage of produce/implements/cattle/servants residence; family part for oversight.

holdings.text: Maxim accessio cedit principali does not make post-grant Wada on Watan land inalienable Watan property.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inalienability attaches only to granted property per Act; maxim doesn't extend to subsequent constructions.

anchor.surface_text: Hanmantrao Annarao v. Dhruvaraj Pandurangrao 1 it was held by the Bombay High Court that the word agriculturist in cls. b and c of the proviso to s. 60 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure denotes persons who are personally engaged in tilling and cultivating the land and whose livel

precedents.cited_proposition: the word agriculturist in cls. b and c of the proviso to s. 60(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure denotes persons who are personally engaged in tilling and cultivating the land and whose livelihood depends upon the proceeds of such tillage and cultivation of the soil. It does not include large landed proprietors even though they may be tilling the land and cultivating it through their servants.
precedents.cited_holding: agriculturist denotes persons personally engaged in tilling, livelihood from that, not large proprietors using servants.

precedents.citation: Parvataneni Lakshmayya v. The Official Receiver of Kistna 2

anchor.surface_text: Parvataneni Lakshmayya v. The Official Receiver of Kistna 2 a Full Bench of the Madras High Court arrived at the following conclusion after considering various decisions of some of the High Courts in India- We think that, having regard to the scheme of the section exempting from attachment, as it does, tools of artisans, and, where the judgment debtor is an agriculturist his implements of husbandry and such cattle and seed-grain as may in the opinion of the Court be necessary to enable him to earn his livelihood, and his houses and other buildings occupied by him, protection is intended to be given to those who are real tillers of the land, and that an agricul- turist in the section is a person who is really dependent for his living on tilling the soil and unable to maintain himself otherwise.

precedents.case_name: Parvataneni Lakshmayya v The Official Receiver of Kistna
precedents.cited_proposition: an agriculturist in the section is a person who is really dependent for his living on tilling the soil and unable to maintain himself otherwise.
precedents.cited_holding: protection for real tillers dependent on tilling the soil.

anchor.surface_text: in the case of Tirloki Prasad Kunj Behari Lal 1 the Allahabad High Court held that the test to be applied in deciding whether a person is an agriculturist is whether his main source of income is derived from cultivation or not.

precedents.case_name: Tirloki Prasad v Kunj Behari Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: test whether main source of income derived from cultivation.

precedents.citation: Dwarka Prasad v. Municipal Board, Meerut 2

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Dwarka Prasad v. Municipal Board, Meerut 2 the same High Court held that there was no reason for holding that cl. b of the proviso to s. 60 1 applied only to the case of very small farmers and not to the case of large farmers.

precedents.case_name: Dwarka Prasad v Municipal Board Meerut
precedents.cited_proposition: cl. b applies to large farmers too, protects implements to continue livelihood.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Gowardhandas v. Mohanlal 3 the conclusions of the Nagpur High Court were Whether a person is an agriculturist or not is not a question turning on source of income but on nature of occupation.

precedents.cited_proposition: agriculturist based on nature of occupation, agriculture, even large scale, through labourers.
precedents.cited_holding: nature of occupation, not source; cultivates with hands or directs labourers.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Nihal Singh v. Siri Ram 1 the Lahore High Court held that the word agriculturist means a person who personally engages in the occupation of tilling the soil and derives his livelihood from that occupation and cannot or does not maintain himself from other sources.

precedents.cited_proposition: personally engages in tilling, livelihood from that, not other sources.
precedents.cited_holding: personal tilling, no other maintenance sources.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Anantalal v. Bibhuti 2 the Patna High Court held that an agriculturist was one who tilled the soil and thereby earned his livelihood and was expected to have implements of husbandry, cattle and seed-grain.

precedents.cited_proposition: tills soil, earns livelihood thereby; cultivation main source though not sole test.

precedents.citation: Muthuvenkatarama Reddiar v. The Official Receiver of South Arcot 1

anchor.surface_text: Muthuvenkatarama Reddiar v. The Official Receiver of South Arcot 1 . This view has been discarded in a later full bench decision of the same High Court in Parvataneni Lakshmayya v. The Official Receiver of Kistna 2 to which reference will be made later.

precedents.case_name: Muthuvenkatarama Reddiar v The Official Receiver of South Arcot
precedents.cited_holding: sole means of livelihood, excluding large farming.
